  function detectColorScheme(){
    var theme="light";
    var current_theme = localStorage.getItem("ar5iv_theme");
    if(current_theme){
      if(current_theme == "dark"){
        theme = "dark";
      } }
    else if(!window.matchMedia) { return false; }
    else if(window.matchMedia("(prefers-color-scheme: dark)").matches) {
      theme = "dark"; }
    if (theme=="dark") {
      document.documentElement.setAttribute("data-theme", "dark");
    } else {
      document.documentElement.setAttribute("data-theme", "light"); } }

  detectColorScheme();

  function toggleColorScheme(){
    var current_theme = localStorage.getItem("ar5iv_theme");
    if (current_theme) {
      if (current_theme == "light") {
        localStorage.setItem("ar5iv_theme", "dark"); }
      else {
        localStorage.setItem("ar5iv_theme", "light"); } }
    else {
        localStorage.setItem("ar5iv_theme", "dark"); }
    detectColorScheme(); }
</script>

<span id="p1.1.4" class="ltx_text"><span id="p1.1.4.1" class="ltx_ERROR undefined">\verbbox</span><span id="p1.1.4.2" class="ltx_ERROR undefined">\verbbox</span></span>

<h1 class="ltx_title ltx_title_document">On the Just-In-Time Discovery of 
<br class="ltx_break">Profit-Generating Transactions in DeFi Protocols</h1>
<div class="ltx_authors">
<span class="ltx_creator ltx_role_author">
<span class="ltx_personname">

Liyi Zhou,
Kaihua Qin,
Antoine Cully,
Benjamin Livshits
and
Arthur Gervais
</span><span class="ltx_author_notes">
<span class="ltx_contact ltx_role_affiliation">
Imperial College London, United Kingdom
<br class="ltx_break">
</span></span></span>
</div>

<div class="ltx_abstract">
<h6 class="ltx_title ltx_title_abstract">Abstract</h6>
<p id="id17.id1" class="ltx_p">Decentralized Finance&nbsp; (DeFi) is a blockchain-asset-enabled finance ecosystem with millions of daily USD transaction volume, billions of locked up USD, as well as a plethora of newly emerging protocols (for lending, staking, and exchanges). Because all transactions, user balances, and total value locked in DeFi are publicly readable, a natural question that arises is: how can we automatically craft profitable transactions across the intertwined DeFi platforms?</p>
<p id="id13.13" class="ltx_p">In this paper, we investigate two methods that allow us to automatically create profitable DeFi trades, one well-suited to arbitrage and the other applicable to more complicated settings. We first adopt the Bellman-Ford-Moore algorithm with <span id="id13.13.1" class="ltx_text ltx_font_smallcaps">DeFiPoser-ARB</span> and then create logical DeFi protocol models for a theorem prover in <span id="id13.13.2" class="ltx_text ltx_font_smallcaps">DeFiPoser-SMT</span>. While <span id="id13.13.3" class="ltx_text ltx_font_smallcaps">DeFiPoser-ARB</span> focuses on DeFi transactions that form a cycle and performs very well for arbitrage, <span id="id13.13.4" class="ltx_text ltx_font_smallcaps">DeFiPoser-SMT</span> can detect more complicated profitable transactions. We estimate that <span id="id13.13.5" class="ltx_text ltx_font_smallcaps">DeFiPoser-ARB</span> and <span id="id13.13.6" class="ltx_text ltx_font_smallcaps">DeFiPoser-SMT</span> can generate an average weekly revenue of&nbsp;<math id="id1.1.m1.1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\numprint{191.48}" display="inline"><semantics id="id1.1.m1.1a"><mn id="id1.1.m1.1.1" xref="id1.1.m1.1.1.cmml">191.48</mn><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="id1.1.m1.1b"><cn type="float" id="id1.1.m1.1.1.cmml" xref="id1.1.m1.1.1">191.48</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="id1.1.m1.1c">\numprint{191.48}</annotation></semantics></math>&nbsp;ETH (<math id="id2.2.m2.2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\numprint{76592}" display="inline"><semantics id="id2.2.m2.2a"><mrow id="id2.2.m2.2.2.4"><mn id="id2.2.m2.1.1.1.1" xref="id2.2.m2.2.2.3.cmml">76</mn><mo id="id2.2.m2.2.2.4.1" xref="id2.2.m2.2.2.3.cmml">,</mo><mn id="id2.2.m2.2.2.2.2" xref="id2.2.m2.2.2.3.cmml">592</mn></mrow><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="id2.2.m2.2b"><cn type="integer" id="id2.2.m2.2.2.3.cmml" xref="id2.2.m2.1.1.1.1">76592</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="id2.2.m2.2c">\numprint{76592}</annotation></semantics></math>&nbsp;USD) and &nbsp;<math id="id3.3.m3.1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\numprint{72.44}" display="inline"><semantics id="id3.3.m3.1a"><mn id="id3.3.m3.1.1" xref="id3.3.m3.1.1.cmml">72.44</mn><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="id3.3.m3.1b"><cn type="float" id="id3.3.m3.1.1.cmml" xref="id3.3.m3.1.1">72.44</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="id3.3.m3.1c">\numprint{72.44}</annotation></semantics></math>&nbsp;ETH (<math id="id4.4.m4.2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\numprint{28976}" display="inline"><semantics id="id4.4.m4.2a"><mrow id="id4.4.m4.2.2.4"><mn id="id4.4.m4.1.1.1.1" xref="id4.4.m4.2.2.3.cmml">28</mn><mo id="id4.4.m4.2.2.4.1" xref="id4.4.m4.2.2.3.cmml">,</mo><mn id="id4.4.m4.2.2.2.2" xref="id4.4.m4.2.2.3.cmml">976</mn></mrow><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="id4.4.m4.2b"><cn type="integer" id="id4.4.m4.2.2.3.cmml" xref="id4.4.m4.1.1.1.1">28976</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="id4.4.m4.2c">\numprint{28976}</annotation></semantics></math>&nbsp;USD) respectively, with the highest transaction revenue being&nbsp;<math id="id5.5.m5.1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\numprint{81.31}" display="inline"><semantics id="id5.5.m5.1a"><mn id="id5.5.m5.1.1" xref="id5.5.m5.1.1.cmml">81.31</mn><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="id5.5.m5.1b"><cn type="float" id="id5.5.m5.1.1.cmml" xref="id5.5.m5.1.1">81.31</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="id5.5.m5.1c">\numprint{81.31}</annotation></semantics></math>&nbsp;ETH (<math id="id6.6.m6.2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\numprint{32524}" display="inline"><semantics id="id6.6.m6.2a"><mrow id="id6.6.m6.2.2.4"><mn id="id6.6.m6.1.1.1.1" xref="id6.6.m6.2.2.3.cmml">32</mn><mo id="id6.6.m6.2.2.4.1" xref="id6.6.m6.2.2.3.cmml">,</mo><mn id="id6.6.m6.2.2.2.2" xref="id6.6.m6.2.2.3.cmml">524</mn></mrow><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="id6.6.m6.2b"><cn type="integer" id="id6.6.m6.2.2.3.cmml" xref="id6.6.m6.1.1.1.1">32524</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="id6.6.m6.2c">\numprint{32524}</annotation></semantics></math>&nbsp;USD) and&nbsp;<math id="id7.7.m7.1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\numprint{22.40}" display="inline"><semantics id="id7.7.m7.1a"><mn id="id7.7.m7.1.1" xref="id7.7.m7.1.1.cmml">22.40</mn><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="id7.7.m7.1b"><cn type="float" id="id7.7.m7.1.1.cmml" xref="id7.7.m7.1.1">22.40</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="id7.7.m7.1c">\numprint{22.40}</annotation></semantics></math>&nbsp;ETH (<math id="id8.8.m8.2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\numprint{8960}" display="inline"><semantics id="id8.8.m8.2a"><mrow id="id8.8.m8.2.2.4"><mn id="id8.8.m8.1.1.1.1" xref="id8.8.m8.2.2.3.cmml">8</mn><mo id="id8.8.m8.2.2.4.1" xref="id8.8.m8.2.2.3.cmml">,</mo><mn id="id8.8.m8.2.2.2.2" xref="id8.8.m8.2.2.3.cmml">960</mn></mrow><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="id8.8.m8.2b"><cn type="integer" id="id8.8.m8.2.2.3.cmml" xref="id8.8.m8.1.1.1.1">8960</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="id8.8.m8.2c">\numprint{8960}</annotation></semantics></math>&nbsp;USD) respectively. We further show that <span id="id13.13.7" class="ltx_text ltx_font_smallcaps">DeFiPoser-SMT</span> finds the known economic bZx attack from February&nbsp;2020, which yields&nbsp;<math id="id9.9.m9.1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="0.48" display="inline"><semantics id="id9.9.m9.1a"><mn id="id9.9.m9.1.1" xref="id9.9.m9.1.1.cmml">0.48</mn><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="id9.9.m9.1b"><cn type="float" id="id9.9.m9.1.1.cmml" xref="id9.9.m9.1.1">0.48</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="id9.9.m9.1c">0.48</annotation></semantics></math>M USD. Our forensic investigations show that this opportunity existed for&nbsp;<math id="id10.10.m10.1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="69" display="inline"><semantics id="id10.10.m10.1a"><mn id="id10.10.m10.1.1" xref="id10.10.m10.1.1.cmml">69</mn><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="id10.10.m10.1b"><cn type="integer" id="id10.10.m10.1.1.cmml" xref="id10.10.m10.1.1">69</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="id10.10.m10.1c">69</annotation></semantics></math> days and could have yielded more revenue if exploited one day earlier. Our evaluation spans&nbsp;<math id="id11.11.m11.1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="150" display="inline"><semantics id="id11.11.m11.1a"><mn id="id11.11.m11.1.1" xref="id11.11.m11.1.1.cmml">150</mn><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="id11.11.m11.1b"><cn type="integer" id="id11.11.m11.1.1.cmml" xref="id11.11.m11.1.1">150</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="id11.11.m11.1c">150</annotation></semantics></math> days, given&nbsp;<math id="id12.12.m12.1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="96" display="inline"><semantics id="id12.12.m12.1a"><mn id="id12.12.m12.1.1" xref="id12.12.m12.1.1.cmml">96</mn><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="id12.12.m12.1b"><cn type="integer" id="id12.12.m12.1.1.cmml" xref="id12.12.m12.1.1">96</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="id12.12.m12.1c">96</annotation></semantics></math> DeFi protocol actions, and&nbsp;<math id="id13.13.m13.1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="25" display="inline"><semantics id="id13.13.m13.1a"><mn id="id13.13.m13.1.1" xref="id13.13.m13.1.1.cmml">25</mn><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="id13.13.m13.1b"><cn type="integer" id="id13.13.m13.1.1.cmml" xref="id13.13.m13.1.1">25</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="id13.13.m13.1c">25</annotation></semantics></math> assets.</p>
<p id="id16.16" class="ltx_p">Looking beyond the financial gains mentioned above, <em id="id16.16.1" class="ltx_emph ltx_font_italic">forks</em> deteriorate the blockchain consensus security, as they increase the risks of double-spending and selfish mining. We explore the implications of <span id="id16.16.2" class="ltx_text ltx_font_smallcaps">DeFiPoser-ARB</span> and <span id="id16.16.3" class="ltx_text ltx_font_smallcaps">DeFiPoser-SMT</span> on blockchain consensus. Specifically, we show that the trades identified by our tools exceed the Ethereum block reward by up to&nbsp;<math id="id14.14.m1.1" class="ltx_math_unparsed" alttext="874\times" display="inline"><semantics id="id14.14.m1.1a"><mrow id="id14.14.m1.1b"><mn id="id14.14.m1.1.1">874</mn><mo lspace="0.222em" id="id14.14.m1.1.2">×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="id14.14.m1.1c">874\times</annotation></semantics></math>. Given optimal adversarial strategies provided by a Markov Decision Process&nbsp;(MDP), we quantify the value threshold at which a profitable transaction qualifies as Miner Extractable Value&nbsp;(MEV) and would incentivize MEV-aware miners to fork the blockchain. For instance, we find that on Ethereum, a miner with a hash rate of&nbsp;<math id="id15.15.m2.1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="10\%" display="inline"><semantics id="id15.15.m2.1a"><mrow id="id15.15.m2.1.1" xref="id15.15.m2.1.1.cmml"><mn id="id15.15.m2.1.1.2" xref="id15.15.m2.1.1.2.cmml">10</mn><mo id="id15.15.m2.1.1.1" xref="id15.15.m2.1.1.1.cmml">%</mo></mrow><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="id15.15.m2.1b"><apply id="id15.15.m2.1.1.cmml" xref="id15.15.m2.1.1"><csymbol cd="latexml" id="id15.15.m2.1.1.1.cmml" xref="id15.15.m2.1.1.1">percent</csymbol><cn type="integer" id="id15.15.m2.1.1.2.cmml" xref="id15.15.m2.1.1.2">10</cn></apply></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="id15.15.m2.1c">10\%</annotation></semantics></math> would fork the blockchain if an MEV opportunity exceeds&nbsp;<math id="id16.16.m3.1" class="ltx_math_unparsed" alttext="4\times" display="inline"><semantics id="id16.16.m3.1a"><mrow id="id16.16.m3.1b"><mn id="id16.16.m3.1.1">4</mn><mo lspace="0.222em" id="id16.16.m3.1.2">×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="id16.16.m3.1c">4\times</annotation></semantics></math> the block reward.</p>
</div>
<section id="S1" class="ltx_section">
<h2 class="ltx_title ltx_title_section">
<span class="ltx_tag ltx_tag_section">I </span><span id="S1.1.1" class="ltx_text ltx_font_smallcaps">Introduction</span>
</h2>

<div id="S1.p1" class="ltx_para">
<p id="S1.p1.1" class="ltx_p">Blockchain-based decentralized finance protocols (commonly referred to as DeFi) have attracted a recent surge in popularity and value stored exceeding&nbsp;<math id="S1.p1.1.m1.1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="13" display="inline"><semantics id="S1.p1.1.m1.1a"><mn id="S1.p1.1.m1.1.1" xref="S1.p1.1.m1.1.1.cmml">13</mn><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S1.p1.1.m1.1b"><cn type="integer" id="S1.p1.1.m1.1.1.cmml" xref="S1.p1.1.m1.1.1">13</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S1.p1.1.m1.1c">13</annotation></semantics></math> billion USD. The currently most popular DeFi platforms are based on the Ethereum blockchain and its system of smart contracts, which regularly gives nascence to new applications, mirrored and inspired by the traditional centralized finance system. Examples are asset exchanges&nbsp;<cite class="ltx_cite ltx_citemacro_cite">[<a href="https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2103.02228#bib.bib24" title="" class="ltx_ref">24</a>, <a href="https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2103.02228#bib.bib58" title="" class="ltx_ref">58</a>]</cite>, margin trading&nbsp;<cite class="ltx_cite ltx_citemacro_cite">[<a href="https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2103.02228#bib.bib24" title="" class="ltx_ref">24</a>, <a href="https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2103.02228#bib.bib3" title="" class="ltx_ref">3</a>]</cite>, lending/borrowing platforms&nbsp;<cite class="ltx_cite ltx_citemacro_cite">[<a href="https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2103.02228#bib.bib30" title="" class="ltx_ref">30</a>, <a href="https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2103.02228#bib.bib27" title="" class="ltx_ref">27</a>]</cite>, and derivatives&nbsp;<cite class="ltx_cite ltx_citemacro_cite">[<a href="https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2103.02228#bib.bib27" title="" class="ltx_ref">27</a>]</cite>. DeFi, moreover, can surprise with novel use-cases such as constant product market maker exchanges&nbsp;<cite class="ltx_cite ltx_citemacro_cite">[<a href="https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2103.02228#bib.bib58" title="" class="ltx_ref">58</a>, <a href="https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2103.02228#bib.bib26" title="" class="ltx_ref">26</a>]</cite> and flash loans&nbsp;—&nbsp;instant loans where the lender bears no risk that the borrower does not repay the loan&nbsp;<cite class="ltx_cite ltx_citemacro_cite">[<a href="https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2103.02228#bib.bib4" title="" class="ltx_ref">4</a>, <a href="https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2103.02228#bib.bib24" title="" class="ltx_ref">24</a>, <a href="https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2103.02228#bib.bib53" title="" class="ltx_ref">53</a>]</cite>.</p>
</div>
<figure id="S1.F1" class="ltx_figure"><img src="./[2103.02228] On the Just-In-Time Discovery of Profit-Generating Transactions in DeFi Protocols_files/system.png" id="S1.F1.g1" class="ltx_graphics ltx_centering ltx_img_landscape" width="598" height="400" alt="Refer to caption">
<figcaption class="ltx_caption ltx_centering"><span class="ltx_tag ltx_tag_figure"><span id="S1.F1.13.1.1" class="ltx_text" style="font-size:90%;">Figure 1</span>: </span><span id="S1.F1.14.2" class="ltx_text ltx_font_smallcaps" style="font-size:90%;">DeFiPoser-ARB<span id="S1.F1.14.2.1" class="ltx_text ltx_font_upright"> and </span>DeFiPoser-SMT<span id="S1.F1.14.2.2" class="ltx_text ltx_font_upright"> system overview. In&nbsp;</span>DeFiPoser-SMT<span id="S1.F1.14.2.3" class="ltx_text ltx_font_upright">, we <span id="S1.F1.14.2.3.1" class="ltx_text" style="position:relative; bottom:0.5pt;">\raisebox{-.9pt} {{2}}⃝</span> Create logical models, <span id="S1.F1.14.2.3.2" class="ltx_text" style="position:relative; bottom:0.5pt;">\raisebox{-.9pt} {{3}}⃝</span> paths are created and trimmed with heuristics and <span id="S1.F1.14.2.3.3" class="ltx_text" style="position:relative; bottom:0.5pt;">\raisebox{-.9pt} {{4}}⃝</span> used within a theorem prover to generate a transaction. In </span>DeFiPoser-ARB<span id="S1.F1.14.2.4" class="ltx_text ltx_font_upright"> we <span id="S1.F1.14.2.4.1" class="ltx_text" style="position:relative; bottom:0.5pt;">\raisebox{-.9pt} {{2}}⃝</span> build a graph of the blockchain state, <span id="S1.F1.14.2.4.2" class="ltx_text" style="position:relative; bottom:0.5pt;">\raisebox{-.9pt} {{3}}⃝</span> identify negative cycles, <span id="S1.F1.14.2.4.3" class="ltx_text" style="position:relative; bottom:0.5pt;">\raisebox{-.9pt} {{4}}⃝</span> perform a local search and repeat. The transaction with the highest revenue is <span id="S1.F1.14.2.4.4" class="ltx_text" style="position:relative; bottom:0.5pt;">\raisebox{-.9pt} {{4}}⃝</span> concretely evaluated before being mined in the next block.</span></span></figcaption>
</figure>
<div id="S1.p2" class="ltx_para">
<p id="S1.p2.1" class="ltx_p">A peculiarity of DeFi platforms is their ability to inter-operate; e.g., one may borrow a cryptocurrency asset on one platform, exchange the asset on another, and for instance, lend the resulting asset on a third system. DeFi’s <em id="S1.p2.1.1" class="ltx_emph ltx_font_italic">composability</em> has led to the emergence of chained trading and arbitrage opportunities throughout the tightly intertwined DeFi space. Reasoning about what this easy composition entails is not particularly simple; on one side, atomic composition allows to perform <em id="S1.p2.1.2" class="ltx_emph ltx_font_italic">risk-free arbitrage</em>&nbsp;—&nbsp;that is to equate asset prices on different DeFi markets. Arbitrage is a benign and important endeavor to keep markets synchronized.</p>
</div>
<div id="S1.p3" class="ltx_para">
<p id="S1.p3.1" class="ltx_p">On the other side, we have seen multi-million-revenue trades that cleverly use the technique of flash loans to exploit <em id="S1.p3.1.1" class="ltx_emph ltx_font_italic">economic states</em> in DeFi protocols (e.g., the economic attack on bZx&nbsp;<cite class="ltx_cite ltx_citemacro_cite">[<a href="https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2103.02228#bib.bib3" title="" class="ltx_ref">3</a>, <a href="https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2103.02228#bib.bib53" title="" class="ltx_ref">53</a>]</cite> Harvest Finance&nbsp;<cite class="ltx_cite ltx_citemacro_cite">[<a href="https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2103.02228#bib.bib28" title="" class="ltx_ref">28</a>]</cite>, Value Defi&nbsp;<cite class="ltx_cite ltx_citemacro_cite">[<a href="https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2103.02228#bib.bib23" title="" class="ltx_ref">23</a>]</cite> and others&nbsp;<cite class="ltx_cite ltx_citemacro_cite">[<a href="https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2103.02228#bib.bib5" title="" class="ltx_ref">5</a>, <a href="https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2103.02228#bib.bib55" title="" class="ltx_ref">55</a>]</cite>).
While exploiting economic states, however, is not a security attack in the traditional sense, the practitioners’ community often frames these high-revenue trades as “hacks.” Yet, the executing trader follows the rules set forth by the deployed smart contracts. Irrespective of the framing, liquidity providers engaging with DeFi experience millions of USD in unexpected losses. This highlights the need for automated tools that help protocol designers and liquidity providers to understand arbitrage and financial implications in general when engaging with DeFi protocols.</p>
</div>
<div id="S1.p4" class="ltx_para ltx_noindent">
<p id="S1.p4.3" class="ltx_p"><span id="S1.p4.3.1" class="ltx_text ltx_font_bold ltx_font_smallcaps">DeFiPoser-ARB<span id="S1.p4.3.1.1" class="ltx_text ltx_font_upright"> and </span>DeFiPoser-SMT<span id="S1.p4.3.1.2" class="ltx_text ltx_font_upright">:</span></span>
This paper presents two tools (cf.&nbsp;Figure&nbsp;<a href="https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2103.02228#S1.F1" title="Figure 1 ‣ I Introduction ‣ On the Just-In-Time Discovery of Profit-Generating Transactions in DeFi Protocols" class="ltx_ref"><span class="ltx_text ltx_ref_tag">1</span></a>) that automatically create transactions to compose existing DeFi protocols to generate revenue that can be extracted from the Ethereum ecosystem. They are designed to run in real-time: at every block, they can find (and execute) a new profit-generating transaction; we show how our running time of an unoptimized implementation requires an average of&nbsp;<math id="S1.p4.1.m1.1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="6.43" display="inline"><semantics id="S1.p4.1.m1.1a"><mn id="S1.p4.1.m1.1.1" xref="S1.p4.1.m1.1.1.cmml">6.43</mn><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S1.p4.1.m1.1b"><cn type="float" id="S1.p4.1.m1.1.1.cmml" xref="S1.p4.1.m1.1.1">6.43</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S1.p4.1.m1.1c">6.43</annotation></semantics></math> seconds and&nbsp;<math id="S1.p4.2.m2.1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="5.39" display="inline"><semantics id="S1.p4.2.m2.1a"><mn id="S1.p4.2.m2.1.1" xref="S1.p4.2.m2.1.1.cmml">5.39</mn><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S1.p4.2.m2.1b"><cn type="float" id="S1.p4.2.m2.1.1.cmml" xref="S1.p4.2.m2.1.1">5.39</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S1.p4.2.m2.1c">5.39</annotation></semantics></math> seconds on a recent Ethereum block (for <span id="S1.p4.3.2" class="ltx_text ltx_font_smallcaps">DeFiPoser-ARB</span> and <span id="S1.p4.3.3" class="ltx_text ltx_font_smallcaps">DeFiPoser-SMT</span> respectively), which is below Ethereum’s average block time of&nbsp;<math id="S1.p4.3.m3.1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="13.5" display="inline"><semantics id="S1.p4.3.m3.1a"><mn id="S1.p4.3.m3.1.1" xref="S1.p4.3.m3.1.1.cmml">13.5</mn><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S1.p4.3.m3.1b"><cn type="float" id="S1.p4.3.m3.1.1.cmml" xref="S1.p4.3.m3.1.1">13.5</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S1.p4.3.m3.1c">13.5</annotation></semantics></math> seconds&nbsp;<cite class="ltx_cite ltx_citemacro_cite">[<a href="https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2103.02228#bib.bib9" title="" class="ltx_ref">9</a>]</cite>. We would like to point out that <span id="S1.p4.3.4" class="ltx_text ltx_font_smallcaps">DeFiPoser-ARB</span> and <span id="S1.p4.3.5" class="ltx_text ltx_font_smallcaps">DeFiPoser-SMT</span>, are best-effort tools: because the state of the blockchain and DeFi platforms may change at each block, it is important to operate in real-time, otherwise found trading opportunities might be outdated. Therefore, we made the choice of prioritizing execution speed over completeness, and we do not claim to find optimal strategies.</p>
</div>
<div id="S1.p5" class="ltx_para">
<p id="S1.p5.1" class="ltx_p">To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to provide automated transaction search mechanisms for composable DeFi protocols. The main risks for a trader using the tools that we consider within this work are currency exposure (i.e., price volatility risks) and the blockchain transaction fees. We discover that significant revenue can be generated with less than&nbsp;<math id="S1.p5.1.m1.1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="1" display="inline"><semantics id="S1.p5.1.m1.1a"><mn id="S1.p5.1.m1.1.1" xref="S1.p5.1.m1.1.1.cmml">1</mn><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S1.p5.1.m1.1b"><cn type="integer" id="S1.p5.1.m1.1.1.cmml" xref="S1.p5.1.m1.1.1">1</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S1.p5.1.m1.1c">1</annotation></semantics></math> ETH of initial capital when using flash loans.</p>
</div>
<div id="S1.p6" class="ltx_para ltx_noindent">
<p id="S1.p6.1" class="ltx_p"><span id="S1.p6.1.1" class="ltx_text ltx_font_bold">Our contributions are as follows:</span></p>
<ul id="S1.I1" class="ltx_itemize">
<li id="S1.I1.i1" class="ltx_item" style="list-style-type:none;">
<span class="ltx_tag ltx_tag_item">•</span> 
<div id="S1.I1.i1.p1" class="ltx_para">
<p id="S1.I1.i1.p1.1" class="ltx_p"><span id="S1.I1.i1.p1.1.1" class="ltx_text ltx_font_bold ltx_font_smallcaps">DeFiPoser-ARB<span id="S1.I1.i1.p1.1.1.1" class="ltx_text ltx_font_upright">:</span></span> We build a directed DeFi market graph and identify negative cycles with the Bellman-Ford-Moore algorithm. A local search then allows us to discover parameters for profitable arbitrage transactions in near-real-time (average of&nbsp;<math id="S1.I1.i1.p1.1.m1.1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="6.43" display="inline"><semantics id="S1.I1.i1.p1.1.m1.1a"><mn id="S1.I1.i1.p1.1.m1.1.1" xref="S1.I1.i1.p1.1.m1.1.1.cmml">6.43</mn><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S1.I1.i1.p1.1.m1.1b"><cn type="float" id="S1.I1.i1.p1.1.m1.1.1.cmml" xref="S1.I1.i1.p1.1.m1.1.1">6.43</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S1.I1.i1.p1.1.m1.1c">6.43</annotation></semantics></math> seconds per block).</p>
</div>
</li>
<li id="S1.I1.i2" class="ltx_item" style="list-style-type:none;">
<span class="ltx_tag ltx_tag_item">•</span> 
<div id="S1.I1.i2.p1" class="ltx_para">
<p id="S1.I1.i2.p1.1" class="ltx_p"><span id="S1.I1.i2.p1.1.1" class="ltx_text ltx_font_bold ltx_font_smallcaps">DeFiPoser-SMT<span id="S1.I1.i2.p1.1.1.1" class="ltx_text ltx_font_upright"> and Space Reduction:</span></span> To discover more demanding trades than arbitrage, we model the DeFi systems using a state transition model, which we translate to a logical representation in the Z3 theorem prover.
We introduce heuristics to significantly prune the search space to achieve a near real-time transaction discovery (average of&nbsp;<math id="S1.I1.i2.p1.1.m1.1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="5.39" display="inline"><semantics id="S1.I1.i2.p1.1.m1.1a"><mn id="S1.I1.i2.p1.1.m1.1.1" xref="S1.I1.i2.p1.1.m1.1.1.cmml">5.39</mn><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S1.I1.i2.p1.1.m1.1b"><cn type="float" id="S1.I1.i2.p1.1.m1.1.1.cmml" xref="S1.I1.i2.p1.1.m1.1.1">5.39</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S1.I1.i2.p1.1.m1.1c">5.39</annotation></semantics></math> seconds per block).</p>
</div>
</li>
<li id="S1.I1.i3" class="ltx_item" style="list-style-type:none;">
<span class="ltx_tag ltx_tag_item">•</span> 
<div id="S1.I1.i3.p1" class="ltx_para">
<p id="S1.I1.i3.p1.4" class="ltx_p"><span id="S1.I1.i3.p1.4.1" class="ltx_text ltx_font_bold">Miner Extractable Value (MEV) and Security:</span>
We show how <span id="S1.I1.i3.p1.4.2" class="ltx_text ltx_font_smallcaps">DeFiPoser-SMT</span> discovers the economic attack on bZx, which yields over&nbsp;<math id="S1.I1.i3.p1.1.m1.1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="0.48" display="inline"><semantics id="S1.I1.i3.p1.1.m1.1a"><mn id="S1.I1.i3.p1.1.m1.1.1" xref="S1.I1.i3.p1.1.m1.1.1.cmml">0.48</mn><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S1.I1.i3.p1.1.m1.1b"><cn type="float" id="S1.I1.i3.p1.1.m1.1.1.cmml" xref="S1.I1.i3.p1.1.m1.1.1">0.48</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S1.I1.i3.p1.1.m1.1c">0.48</annotation></semantics></math>M USD, and that this opportunity window was open for over&nbsp;<math id="S1.I1.i3.p1.2.m2.1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="69" display="inline"><semantics id="S1.I1.i3.p1.2.m2.1a"><mn id="S1.I1.i3.p1.2.m2.1.1" xref="S1.I1.i3.p1.2.m2.1.1.cmml">69</mn><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S1.I1.i3.p1.2.m2.1b"><cn type="integer" id="S1.I1.i3.p1.2.m2.1.1.cmml" xref="S1.I1.i3.p1.2.m2.1.1">69</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S1.I1.i3.p1.2.m2.1c">69</annotation></semantics></math> days. Given optimal adversarial mining strategies provided by a Markov Decision Process, we show quantitatively that MEV opportunities can deteriorate the blockchain security. For example, a rational MEV-aware miner with a hash rate of&nbsp;<math id="S1.I1.i3.p1.3.m3.1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="10\%" display="inline"><semantics id="S1.I1.i3.p1.3.m3.1a"><mrow id="S1.I1.i3.p1.3.m3.1.1" xref="S1.I1.i3.p1.3.m3.1.1.cmml"><mn id="S1.I1.i3.p1.3.m3.1.1.2" xref="S1.I1.i3.p1.3.m3.1.1.2.cmml">10</mn><mo id="S1.I1.i3.p1.3.m3.1.1.1" xref="S1.I1.i3.p1.3.m3.1.1.1.cmml">%</mo></mrow><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S1.I1.i3.p1.3.m3.1b"><apply id="S1.I1.i3.p1.3.m3.1.1.cmml" xref="S1.I1.i3.p1.3.m3.1.1"><csymbol cd="latexml" id="S1.I1.i3.p1.3.m3.1.1.1.cmml" xref="S1.I1.i3.p1.3.m3.1.1.1">percent</csymbol><cn type="integer" id="S1.I1.i3.p1.3.m3.1.1.2.cmml" xref="S1.I1.i3.p1.3.m3.1.1.2">10</cn></apply></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S1.I1.i3.p1.3.m3.1c">10\%</annotation></semantics></math> will fork the blockchain if an MEV opportunity exceeds&nbsp;<math id="S1.I1.i3.p1.4.m4.1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="4" display="inline"><semantics id="S1.I1.i3.p1.4.m4.1a"><mn id="S1.I1.i3.p1.4.m4.1.1" xref="S1.I1.i3.p1.4.m4.1.1.cmml">4</mn><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S1.I1.i3.p1.4.m4.1b"><cn type="integer" id="S1.I1.i3.p1.4.m4.1.1.cmml" xref="S1.I1.i3.p1.4.m4.1.1">4</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S1.I1.i3.p1.4.m4.1c">4</annotation></semantics></math> times the block reward and the miner failed to claim the source of MEV.</p>
</div>
</li>
<li id="S1.I1.i4" class="ltx_item" style="list-style-type:none;">
<span class="ltx_tag ltx_tag_item">•</span> 
<div id="S1.I1.i4.p1" class="ltx_para">
<p id="S1.I1.i4.p1.11" class="ltx_p"><span id="S1.I1.i4.p1.11.1" class="ltx_text ltx_font_bold">Trading Strategy Validation:</span>
We validate the trading strategies discovered by <span id="S1.I1.i4.p1.11.2" class="ltx_text ltx_font_smallcaps">DeFiPoser-ARB</span> and <span id="S1.I1.i4.p1.11.3" class="ltx_text ltx_font_smallcaps">DeFiPoser-SMT</span> on a locally-deployed blockchain that mirrors the real network. We estimate that the found strategies yield&nbsp;<math id="S1.I1.i4.p1.1.m1.2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\numprint{4103.22}" display="inline"><semantics id="S1.I1.i4.p1.1.m1.2a"><mrow id="S1.I1.i4.p1.1.m1.2.2.4"><mn id="S1.I1.i4.p1.1.m1.1.1.1.1" xref="S1.I1.i4.p1.1.m1.2.2.3.cmml">4</mn><mo id="S1.I1.i4.p1.1.m1.2.2.4.1" xref="S1.I1.i4.p1.1.m1.2.2.3.cmml">,</mo><mn id="S1.I1.i4.p1.1.m1.2.2.2.2" xref="S1.I1.i4.p1.1.m1.2.2.3.cmml">103.22</mn></mrow><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S1.I1.i4.p1.1.m1.2b"><cn type="float" id="S1.I1.i4.p1.1.m1.2.2.3.cmml" xref="S1.I1.i4.p1.1.m1.1.1.1.1">4103.22</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S1.I1.i4.p1.1.m1.2c">\numprint{4103.22}</annotation></semantics></math>&nbsp;ETH (<math id="S1.I1.i4.p1.2.m2.3" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\numprint{1641288}" display="inline"><semantics id="S1.I1.i4.p1.2.m2.3a"><mrow id="S1.I1.i4.p1.2.m2.3.3.5"><mn id="S1.I1.i4.p1.2.m2.1.1.1.1" id="S1.I1.i4.p1.2.m2.3.3.5.2" xref="S1.I1.i4.p1.2.m2.3.3.4.cmml">,</mo><mn id="S1.I1.i4.p1.2.m2.3.3.3.3" xref="S1.I1.i4.p1.2.m2.3.3.4.cmml">288</mn></mrow><annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S1.I1.i4.p1.2.m2.3b"><cn type="integer" id="S1.I1.i4.p1.2.m2.3.3.4.cmml" xref="S1.I1.i4.p1.2.m2.1.1.1.1">1641288</cn></annotation-xml><annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S1.I1.i4.p1.2.m2.3c">\numprint{1641288}</annotation></semantics></math>&nbsp;USD) and <math id="S1.I1.i4.p1.3.m3.2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\numprint{1552.32}" display="inline"><semantics id="S1.I1.i4.p1.3.m3.2a"><mrow id="S1.I1.i4.p1.3.m3.2.2.4"><mn id="S1.I1.i4.p1.3.m3.1.1.1.1" xref="S1.I1.i4.p1.3.m3.2.2.3.cmml">1</mn><mo id="S1.I1.i4.p1.3.m3.2.2.4.1" id="S1.I1.i4.p1.3.m3.2c">\numprint{1552.32}</annotation></semantics></math>&nbsp;ETH (<math id="S1.I1.i4.p1.4.m4.2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\numprint{620928}" display="inline"><semantics
